titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the J. Hector St. John de Crèvecoeur Papers
St. John de Crèvecoeur (J. Hector) Papers
titlestmt.author: by Diane J. Ducharme

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Wednesday March 27, 2019 at 03:08

did.unittitle: J. Hector St. John de Crèvecoeur papers

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The J. Hector St. John de Crèvecoeur Papers consist of manuscripts and printed material documenting aspects of the later life and work of the French author, best known for his 1782 Letters from an American Farmer.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: St. John de Crèvecoeur, J. Hector, 1735-1813

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Almost all of the papers were purchased from the 19th Century Shop on the Edwin J. Beinecke Book Fund and the Frederick W. and Carrie S. Beinecke Fund for Western Americana, 2006.
The 1784-1786 letterbook of Crèvecoeur family correspondence was purchased from the William Reese Company on the Henry C. Taylor Fund, 2006.
The corrected proofs of Voyage dans la Haute Pennsylvanie et dans l'Ètat de New-York were purchased from the William Reese Company on the Edwin J. Beinecke Book Fund, 2006.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The J. Hector St. John de Crèvecoeur Papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: J. Hector St. John de Crèvecoeur Papers. General Collection, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University.

bioghist.head: J. Hector St. John de Crèvecoeur (1735-1813)
bioghist.p: J. Hector St. John de Crèvecoeur was born and educated in Caen, Normandy. In 1755 he became a surveyor in the French Colonial Militia and fought at the battle of Fort George in 1757. Crèvecoeur was wounded at the battle of Quebec, after which he left the army for unknown reasons and sailed to New York in December, 1759. On arrival, he changed his name to J. Hector St. John. For the next decade, Crèvecoeur earned his livelihood as a trader, explorer and surveyor, traveling through all of the British North American colonies. He became a naturalized citizen of New York Colony in 1765.

In 1769 he married Mehitable Tippet, the daughter of a prominent Dutchess County family, and purchased 120 acres of farmland in Orange County. The next several years brought Crèvecoeur three children and increasing prosperity; his farm flourished,and he led a county project to drain arable meadows and reclaim farmland. Crèvecoeur kept a daily journal of observations on his experiences and on his adopted country, which he considered "the most perfect society in the world."

The advent of the American Revolution disrupted this happiness. Crèvecoeur's attempts to remain neutral won him suspicion and hostility from both sides of the conflict. In 1779, he decided to return to France to establish his children's right to inherit the family's lands in Normandy. Arrested by the British in New York City as a suspected enemy collaborator, he was imprisoned for months, but finally sailed for Europe in September of 1780. His ship was wrecked off the coast of Ireland, and he did not reach Normandy until August of 1781.

Crèvecoeur's Letters from an American Farmer was published in London early in 1782. It received international praise, appeared in several English and Irish editions, and was translated into German and Dutch. On the verge of America's independence, Crèvecoeur was the first author to provide an answer to the European question of the day: "What then is this American, this new man?"

Crèvecoeur was considered one of the foremost European authorities on the new country, and France appointed him consul to New York, New Jersey, and Connecticut. He sailed for New York on the ship that carried the first copy of the Treaty of Paris to the United States. When he arrived, he discovered that his wife had died and his children had been taken in by their neighbors; his farm and its buildings had been destroyed by Native American allies of the British.

As Consul, Crèvecoeur worked to increase French-American trade and supported cultural and artistic exchanges. He was also a patron of botanical gardens, experiments with steamships, and the first Roman Catholic church in New York City. His greatly enlarged and reorganized French version of Letters was published in Paris in 1784. His many American friends included Thomas Jefferson and Benjamin Franklin. St. Johnsbury, Vermont, was named after Crèvecoeur, in 1789 he was made a member of the American Philsophical Society.

Crèvecoeur returned to France in 1790, but the dangers of the French Revolution led him to retire unpensioned in 1792 and to withdraw into his family life. In 1801 he published his Voyage dans la haute Pennsylvanie et dans l'Ètat de New York ; the work was not popular, and was not translated into English until 1961. Crèvecoeur spent his final years at his farm in Lesches, France, and visiting his extended family. He died at Sarcelles, near Paris, in 1813.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The J. Hector St. John de Crèvecoeur Papers document aspects of the later life and writings of J. Hector St. John de Crèvecoeur, particularly the expanded French version of his Letters from an American Farmer (1784) and his final work, Voyage dans la haute Pennsylvanie et dans l'Ètat de New York (1801). The collection includes family correspondence, manuscripts, and research materials, mostly focused on social and political conditions in the United States during the first decades of its existence as a nation.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into three series: I. Correspondence and Family Papers, 1784-1880. II. Writings, 1786-1801. III. Research Materials, 1784-1812.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series I is arranged by type of material and then alphabetically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series I includes correspondence and family papers. Correspondence includes a letterbook containing letters from Crèvecoeur and from members of the French nobility to his sons. Family Papers include biographical notes compiled by Crèvecoeur's grandson and accounts from Crèvecoeur's attempt to run a packet-ship service.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 23 letters from Crèvecoeur to his sons, Guillaume-Alexandre and Phillippe-Louis, almost all in English, containing discussion of the boys' educations and social development; Crèvecoeur's business affairs, including his attempt to establish a packet-ship service between France and the United States; and his progress on the third volume of Lettres d'un cultivateur Amèricain .

With 3 letters from Crèvecoeur's daughter, America-Frances ("Fanny") to her father and 30 letters from various members of the French nobility addressed to Crèvecoeur's sons. Correspondents include the comtesse d'Houdetôt, Crèvecoeur's patron; the duc de la Rochefoucauld-Liancourt, and the Baron de Breteuil.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Accounts related to the packet-ship service started by Crèvecoeur.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Notes compiled by Robert de Crèvecoeur during his research for his biography of his grandfather ( St. John de Crèvecoeur: sa vie et ses oeuvres , 1883). Includes chronologies, a calendar of correspondence, notes on various persons, and brief essay drafts.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series II contains manuscript and annotated printed material related to two of Crèvecoeur's works, Lettres d'un cultivateur Amèricain and Voyage dans la Haute Pensylvanie et dans l'Ètat de New-York .

unittitle.title: Les Treise Chapitres du Troisième Volume du Cultivateur Amèricain

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph manuscript, heavily corrected and revised, of twelve of the seventeen chapters of the third volume of the French version of Letters from an American Farmer.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Bound in: printed pamphlet, Extrait des gazettes amèricains (Paris, 1786).

unittitle.title: Voyage dans la Haute Pensylvanie et dans l'Ètat de New-York

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes Précis du Chapitres au Second Volume (18 p.); À George Washington (20 p.); notes on William Penn; and notes numbered 22-60, presumably for a chapter in the work.

did.unittitle: Map: Jonction des Rivières Delaware et Susquehannah
Map: The Southern Parts of the Patent of Elisian Fields

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Heavily corrected and annotated in Crèvecoeur's hand, with new manuscript pages tipped in.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Heavily corrected and annotated in Crèvecoeur's hand, with new manuscript pages tipped in.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Heavily corrected and annotated in Crèvecoeur's hand, with new manuscript pages tipped in.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by type of material.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series III contains manuscripts by Crèvecoeur, other manuscript materials, newspaper clippings and newspapers, and printed material, almost all documenting Crèvecoeur's research on aspects of the United States. Manuscripts in his hand include extracts from other works on the United States; a discussion of Franco-American relations; and a notebook containing statistics on various American states. Other manuscript material includes a copy of a John Fothergill letter and a description of George Washington's entrance into New York.

Newspaper clippings, sorted by topic, were collected by Crèvecoeur and reflect his interest in such subjects as religion in America, American educational institutions and learned societies, and slavery.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contents include extracts from Michaux's Travels to the Westward of the Allegany Mountains; notes on the new state of Ohio; descriptions of Native Americans ("Sauvages"); descriptions of Annapolis, Mount Vernon and Monticello; and brief entries on a variety of other topics.
Also includes an eight page summary of The Three Sultanas , accompanied by a printed title page, and several pages of pasted-in newspaper clippings on American subjects.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Notebook compiled during a trip to Munich. Contents include statistics concerning the United States, including populations of the states and territories, distances between major cities, and amounts of agricultural produce. Also contains notes on European history and law. Title from front cover.
Also contains: Postschrift von Deutschland...1793 .

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Manuscript, incomplete, discussing the situations and conditions of Francophone residents of the United States and Canada; the promotion of emigration from France to America; and Franco-American trade relations.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Notes, mathematical calculations and a drawing of a mechanical device.

Written on the reverse of Map of the Middle States of North America with Part of Canada, shewing the situation of the principal towns, viz. Columbia, Baltimore, Philadelphia, New York, Newport (Rhode Island) Boston & Montreal, also their several communications with respect to Lake Ontario . undated.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: List of the contents of three notebooks (not present) documenting the Constitutional Convention.

unittitle.title: Letter from John Fothergill to a Gentleman of Massachusetts-Bay

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Copy of a letter originally dated October 20, 1780 in which Fothergill discusses the War of Independence and the possible future relationship of Great Britain and the former colonies.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Copies, in English and French, of brief letters concerning trade between the United States and France.

unittitle.title: Order de la grande procession que eu lieu let 4 juillet 1788 à Philadelphie

did.unittitle: Plans and elevations of buildings and gardens
Natural history and other scientific topics
Official statements, decrees, and parliamentary reports

unittitle.title: The Independent Chronicle and the Universal Advertiser

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contents include an announcement by Crèvecoeur ("St. John") of the publication of the Journal de medicine .

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contents include a lengthy Extrait d'une lettre du president de l'Universitie de New-York .

unittitle.title: A Plan of Captain Carver's Travels in the Interior Parts of North America in 1766 and 1767

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Annotations in Crèvecoeur's hand on blank final page.
Date given in original as: 10 floréal an. 8.
